CatDescriptText: Mr. Louis Gideon, shoe shop worker, East Liberty and Mr. Roderick Ward, postal worker, Schenley Heights, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper July 22, 1961, pg. 7 with question: "Do you believe Negroes in Pittsburgh are as militant about Civil Rights like others of their race display in other Metropolitan areas in the USA? Why?"  Mr. Gideon's answer reads: "I don't think so.  I believe Pittsburgh Negroes are too complacent.  They are willing to sit down and to let somebody else do the fighting for them..."  Mr. Ward's answer reads: "No, I don't and I think it's mainly because the leadership, such as it is, is divided.  There is not much organization so far as the aims and direction of a program for the attainment of civil rights..."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Louis Gideon wearing light colored short sleeve shirt with embroidery above left breast, standing on sidewalk in front of street with buildings; Portrait of Roderick Ward wearing fedora, eyeglasses, and tweed jacket, standing on sidewalk in front of street with buildings
